references: Furthermore, according to the 3GPP standard [36], we consider that MBS and SBSs operate in adjacent sub 6-GHz frequencies, where we assume the total bandwidth available at the SBSs, operating at the same carrier frequency, is B𝐵B. This bandwidth is later shared amongst the associated UEs of the logical learning groups using an orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDMA) technique. In particular, for a given number of ΔΔ\Delta sub-bands, the available bandwidth B𝐵B is equally divided into several resource blocks (RBs). Therefore, each RB, which is defined as a sub-band in SBS with the bandwidth of M^R​B=BΔsubscript^𝑀𝑅𝐵𝐵Δ\hat{M}_{RB}=\frac{B}{\Delta}. Thereby, the total number of resource blocks (RBs) is MR​B=S×Δsubscript𝑀𝑅𝐵𝑆ΔM_{RB}=S\times\Delta. Furthermore, in a multi-connectivity scenario, UEs can be associated with one or more SBSs based on the reference signal received power (RSRP) [35]. Furthermore, UEs can also change their associations with the SBSs following a certain rule. Hence, we draw a conclusion that multi-connectivity allows UEs to execute propose-and-reject algorithms following a matching game so as to improve their utility [18], [19]. In what follows, the MBS manages the UEs control plane and the data transmission is accomplished by the SBSs. Table I provides the summary of key notations used in this work.

references: We set a single MBS with the maximum system bandwidth as 333 MHz, carrier frequency of 222 GHz[35]. Unless stated otherwise, we set |𝒮|=3×3𝒮33|\mathcal{S}|=3\times 3, i.e., 3 SBS per sector. The maximum transmit power is set as 23 dBm, and shadow fading standard is 3 dB. The UEs are assume to follow Homogeneous Poisson Point Process distribution (HPPP) between 222 m and 100100100 m in the network radius of 100100100 m777To simplify, we consider a small network topology.. Furthermore, we define fnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}^{\max} is uniformly distributed in the range 1.0∼2.0similar-to1.02.01.0\sim 2.0 GHz. In order to evaluate our proposal system model, we choose a set of users in between 10∼100similar-to1010010\sim 100 and the local model size range from 1000.01000.01000.0 to 8000.08000.08000.0 (KB) with mean value around 2712.02712.02712.0 (KB), and median is around 2250.02250.02250.0 (KB). The details of simulation parameters is in Table II.

In Fig. 4, we present a snapshot of our network model. We set a network with the number of UEs at N=100𝑁100N=100 and the number of SBSs at S=5𝑆5S=5 using the aforementioned system variables and the simulations parameters in Table II. Each “circle” in Fig. 4 denotes a UE, and UEs in color are associated with respective colored SBSs. The Fig. 4 shows a double-sided many-to-one matching solution, similar in [46], when realizing Edge-DemLearn algorithm. We observe the UEs are associated with respective SBSs in such a way that enhances the overall system utility while minimizing the learning time objective in the HetNet architecture.
